instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the development of an efficient algorithm to identify organic explosives on polymeric surfaces?
Output: Laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) was used in the related study.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to identify organic explosives on polymeric surfaces?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to identify organic explosives on polymeric surfaces were the association of laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) and machine learning methods.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the classification algorithm and how far can this metric go in identifying organic explosives on polymeric surfaces?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the classification algorithm was the false negative rate. This metric can achieve a false negative rate as low as 2% in identifying organic explosives on polymeric surfaces.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the development of the algorithm to identify organic explosives on polymeric surfaces using LIBS?
Output: Principal components analysis (PCA), partial least squares and discriminant analysis (PLS-DA), soft independent modeling for class analogy (SIMCA), the method of normalized coordinates (MNC), and supervised learning methods (SLM) were explored for the task of identifying organic explosives on polymeric surfaces using LIBS.

instruction: How accurate is the developed classification algorithm in differentiating between organic explosives and ordinary products on polymeric surfaces using laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) technology?
Output: The developed classification algorithm using laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) technology is highly accurate in differentiating between organic explosives and ordinary products on polymeric surfaces. The algorithm has rates of false negatives and false positives below 5%, which demonstrates its effectiveness in accurately labeling residues according to their harmful nature. This level of accuracy is crucial for a realistic application of LIBS in countering explosive threats.
